image.altText: A horse tethered to harness gear.

image.altText: Zane Mellor in a pool reaches for the camera.

title.children: Anguish for mum of Hillcrest jumping castle victim as legal tussle over inquest delays 'justice'

image.altText: A white tractor.

items.synopsis: Pre-1982 tractors should be banned from commercial use, a Tasmanian coroner says, following the death of a father and son in separate accidents while using the same kind of tractor, 43 years apart.

title.children: Same tractor that killed father kills son 43 years later, as coroner calls for ban

image.altText: A composite of three sportswomen in pale blue uniforms celebrating.

image.altText: A desert kurrajong tree sits against a purple night sky.

items.synopsis: Against the dry, arid landscapes of west and central Australia, these trees not only catch your eye, but are a source of food and water and can point you in the right direction if you're lost.

title.children: The desert kurrajong looks like a child's drawing of a tree, but in the outback it can be a lifesaver

image.altText: Angus Cloud, dressed in a purple top, clasps his hands together on the red carpet.

items.synopsis: The actor, best known for playing drug dealer Fezco in HBO show Euphoria, has died aged 25.

title.children: Euphoria actor Angus Cloud dies

image.altText: Pat Cummins holds the Ashes urn while standing in a group of his fellow players

items.synopsis: An Ashes series that delivered on every promise ends in a 2-2 draw, but with enough memories, emotions and stories to last a lifetime, writes Dean Bilton.

title.children: An unforgettable Ashes series ends in a draw, but provides enough stories to last a lifetime

image.altText: A close up of a female police officer in uniform and glasses, giving a press conference in front of a backdrop with the AFP logo

items.synopsis: Today's latest news, as it happens.

title.children: Police reveal 'chilling' charges against former childcare worker who allegedly abused 91 kids — follow the latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Queensland Police Service Acting Assistant Commissioner Col Briggs says today's announcement comes after years of investigations. "From the moment [Operation] Argos located images of victim children being shared on the dark web in 2014, an extensive examination was launched to identify the children in the pictures," he says. "The challenges posed by an investigation of this type were significant and officers never gave up on identifying this alleged offender, reminding themselves that everything you do online leaves a trace."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Police say images shared on the dark web in 2014 led to their investigation

children.content: Queensland Police Service Acting Assistant Commissioner Col Briggs says today's announcement comes after years of investigations.
"From the moment [Operation] Argos located images of victim children being shared on the dark web in 2014, an extensive examination was launched to identify the children in the pictures," he says.

"The challenges posed by an investigation of this type were significant and officers never gave up on identifying this alleged offender, reminding themselves that everything you do online leaves a trace."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A former childcare worker has been charged with 1,623 child abuse offences against 91 children, police have revealed. The Gold Coast man, 45, has been charged with 136 counts of rape and 110 counts of sexual intercourse with a child under 10. AFP Assistant Commissioner Justine Gough says the AFP and its partner agencies never gave up trying to identify the alleged offender and the children involved. "Given there were so many alleged images and videos of children recorded over 15 years on the alleged offender's devices, the process of identification took time, skill and determination," she says. "While I am extremely proud of law enforcements' persistence and their unwavering dedication to identify this alleged offender, and stop further abuse, this is chilling news. "It is with a heavy heart that the AFP and other law enforcement dedicate so much time and resources to prevent and take action against individuals who commit heinous crimes against children. "There is not much solace I can give parents and children who have been identified under Operation Tenterfield, but I can tell you that we never gave up, and we never will when it comes to protecting children. "This is a distressing time for families, carers and the community broadly." You can read more on this story at the link below. If you or anyone you know needs help: Suicide Call Back Service on 1300 659 467 Lifeline on 13 11 14 Aboriginal & Torres Strait Islander crisis support line 13YARN on 13 92 76 Kids Helpline on 1800 551 800 Beyond Blue on 1300 224 636 Headspace on 1800 650 890 ReachOut at au.reachout.com MensLine Australia on 1300 789 978
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Police share 'chilling news' of a former childcare worker charged with 1,623 child abuse offences

featuredLink.title: Former childcare worker charged with more than 1,600 child sex offences

children.content: A former childcare worker has been charged with
1,623 child abuse offences against 91 children
, police have revealed.
The Gold Coast man, 45, has been charged with 136 counts of rape and 110 counts of sexual intercourse with a child under 10.

props.alt: A police woman giving a press conference

children.content: (ABC News)
AFP Assistant Commissioner Justine Gough says the AFP and its partner agencies
never gave up trying to identify the alleged offender and the children involved
"Given there were so many alleged images and videos of children recorded over 15 years on the alleged offender's devices, the process of identification took time, skill and determination," she says.
"While I am extremely proud of law enforcements' persistence and their unwavering dedication to identify this alleged offender, and stop further abuse, this is chilling news.
"It is with a heavy heart that the AFP and other law enforcement dedicate so much time and resources to prevent and take action against individuals who commit heinous crimes against children.

"There is not much solace I can give parents and children who have been identified under Operation Tenterfield, but I can tell you that we never gave up, and we never will when it comes to protecting children.
"This is a distressing time for families, carers and the community broadly."
You can read more on this story at the link below.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Celebrities and actors from HBO series Euphoria have shared tributes to US actor Angus Cloud, who has died at the age of 25. Cloud played drug dealer Fezco in Euphoria. The likes of Javon Walton (who plays Ashtray), Swarm star Chloe Bailey, and rapper Denzel Curry have shared tributes: If you or anyone you know needs help: Suicide Call Back Service on 1300 659 467 Lifeline on 13 11 14 Aboriginal & Torres Strait Islander crisis support line 13YARN on 13 92 76 Kids Helpline on 1800 551 800 Beyond Blue on 1300 224 636 Headspace on 1800 650 890 ReachOut at au.reachout.com MensLine Australia on 1300 789 978

title.children: 'I've been ripping you off for a long, long time': Former accountant pleads guilty to fraud

image.altText: On a shelf of coral, some corals are a stark white colour.

items.synopsis: The Great Barrier Reef is likely to avoid being listed as in danger for at least another year as a United Nations body recommends delaying a decision on its World Heritage status.

image.altText: A young woman with blonde hair sits in a room and smiles.

title.children: Chalmers says Australia making 'welcome progress' in inflation fight but 'not there yet' as RBA weighs possible rate hike

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Home loan refinancing continued at a record-high pace in June, with $20.2 billion worth of loans refinanced, according to the latest data by the ABS. The value had fallen by 3.1% compared to the rate seen in May, but remains significantly higher than a year ago. The head of finance statistics for the ABS, Mish Tan, says the ongoing surge in refinancing is reflective of a higher interest rate environment. "Refinancing activity has remained at record highs in recent months, as borrowers continued to switch lenders amid interest rate rises ," she said. "The value of total refinancing between lenders was 12.6% higher in June compared to a year ago." The number of people taking out mortgages fell by 2.8% in June to a value of $15.9 billion, while investors taking out loans was up by 2.6% to $8.7 billion — however it is 15% lower than this time last year. There was also a 0.8% fall in first home buyers taking out mortgages in June. The ABS also noted that the number of loan commitments in June was around half of what was seen in January 2021 (which is when first home buyer lending peaked during the pandemic — only months after Philip Lowe first mentioned the RBA wasn't expecting to increase the cash rate for "at least three years").
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Home loan refinancing remains high as interest rates bite mortgage holders

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Lynas Rare Earths has signed an updated contract with the US Department of Defense for the construction of the heavy rare earths component of its rare earths processing plant in Texas. The world's largest rare earths producer outside of China says the US government has increased its funding from $120 million ($179 million) to about $258 million ($385 million) for the project. The Texas plant will serve both the US defence department and commercial customers. Lynas says the facility, which is expected to open in 2026, will be the only scale producer of separated heavy rare earths outside of China. Here's Lynas chief executive Amanda Lacaze: "Our heavy rare earths separation plant will be the first of its kind outside China and will help establish a globally significant, safe and environmentally responsible rare earths supply chain." The deal is part of the US government's critical minerals strategy, which aims to diversify supply away from China, develop substitutes and improve reuse and recycling. Heavy rare earths are used in virtually every industry including for high-power magnets, fluorescent lighting, lasers, fibre-optic technology, and solar panels.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Lynas signs $385 million deal with US government

children.content: Lynas Rare Earths has signed an updated contract with the US Department of Defense for the construction of the heavy rare earths component of its rare earths processing plant in Texas.
The world's largest rare earths producer outside of China says the US government has increased its funding from $120 million ($179 million) to about $258 million ($385 million) for the project.
The Texas plant will serve both the US defence department and commercial customers.
Lynas says the facility, which is expected to open in 2026, will be the only scale producer of separated heavy rare earths outside of China.
Here's Lynas chief executive Amanda Lacaze:
"Our heavy rare earths separation plant will be the first of its kind outside China and will help establish a globally significant, safe and environmentally responsible rare earths supply chain."
The deal is part of the US government's critical minerals strategy, which aims to diversify supply away from China, develop substitutes and improve reuse and recycling.
Heavy rare earths are used in virtually every industry including for high-power magnets, fluorescent lighting, lasers, fibre-optic technology, and solar panels.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Commonwealth Bank has put aside $212 million to cover the cost of absorbing Bankwest's business loan book into its portfolio. The bank has also taken a hit from the cost of a one-off levy for the compensation of a last-resort scheme put in place by the federal government. CBA's annual results will be announced next Wednesday. CBA shares are down 0.4 per cent to $105.32.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Commonwealth Bank confirms $212 million provision ahead of FY2023 results

children.content: The Commonwealth Bank has put aside $212 million to cover the cost of absorbing Bankwest's business loan book into its portfolio.
The bank has also taken a hit from the cost of a one-off levy for the compensation of a last-resort scheme put in place by the federal government.
CBA's annual results will be announced next Wednesday.
CBA shares are down 0.4 per cent to $105.32.
